title: 106_s226
content:
The Act titled "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999" declares policy findings. The Act titled "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999" highlights the negative impact of successive military regimes in Nigeria, praises the progress made by the current regime under Gen. Abdusalami Abubakar, acknowledges efforts to combat drug trafficking, and emphasizes the importance of transitioning to civilian rule. Since 1993, the United States and other international members have imposed sanctions on Nigeria for human rights violations and political repression. Despite some progress in protecting freedoms, decrees still exist that suspend constitutional rights, allow indefinite detention without charge, and limit civilian court jurisdiction. Nigeria is obligated to conduct fair elections under international agreements. Nigeria, as a signatory to international agreements, is obligated to conduct fair elections and ensure the free expression of the will of the electors. The country has played a significant role in peacekeeping efforts in Liberia and Sierra Leone. Despite progress, recent events in the Niger Delta highlight the need for ongoing monitoring to prevent a return to repressive methods. The United States should support reforms to promote the rule of law and respect for human rights in Nigeria. The United States should encourage political, economic, and legal reforms in Nigeria to ensure respect for human rights and a transition to democratic civilian government. The sense of Congress is that the President should coordinate with other countries to promote the rule of law, human rights, and democratic civilian government. Additionally, the President should condemn human rights abuses in Nigeria and support the renewal of the mandate for the special rapporteur on Nigeria at the United Nations Human Rights Commission. Development Assistance for Nigeria should include not less than $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, and $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 to promote democracy, good governance, and the rule of law through nongovernmental organizations representing a broad cross-section of Nigerian society. The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) must ensure that NGOs in Nigeria represent a diverse society and aim to promote democracy, human rights, and accountable government. Grants of at least $500,000 per fiscal year are allocated to USAID to support individuals or NGOs working to advance human rights in Nigeria. Additionally, funding of at least $1,000,000 for 2000, $1,500,000 for 2001, and $2,000,000 for 2002 is provided to the United States Information Agency for information assistance. In fiscal years 2000, 2001, and 2002, funding of $1,000,000, $1,500,000, and $2,000,000 respectively is allocated to the United States Information Agency to support activities in Nigeria promoting democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. Congress acknowledges the inadequate staff levels at the USAID office in Lagos, Nigeria, and recommends increasing personnel to effectively carry out their mission. The United States Information Agency is allocated funding to support activities in Nigeria promoting democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. Congress recommends increasing personnel at the USAID office in Lagos, Nigeria to effectively carry out their mission. Staff resources may also be considered for placement elsewhere in Nigeria. SEC. 5 prohibits economic and military assistance to the government of Nigeria and requires opposition to multilateral assistance for Nigeria. Prohibition on Economic Assistance to the Government of Nigeria includes restrictions on various forms of economic aid, excluding disaster relief, refugee assistance, and narcotics control aid. Prohibition on Military Assistance or Arms Transfers to Nigeria includes restrictions on providing military assistance or arms transfers, as defined by specific sections of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The text discusses restrictions on military assistance or arms transfers to Nigeria, including limitations on various forms of assistance such as international military education and training, foreign military financing, and the transfer of defense articles and services under the Arms Export Control Act. Additionally, there is a requirement for the Secretary of the Treasury to oppose multilateral assistance through international financial institutions. The Secretary of the Treasury must instruct the US executive director to oppose any assistance to the Government of Nigeria from specified international financial institutions, including the African Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund. SENSE OF CONGRESS REGARDING ADMISSION INTO THE UNITED STATES OF CERTAIN NIGERIAN NATIONALS: Congress believes that if a democratic transition to civilian rule has not occurred in Nigeria by July 1, 1999, visas should be denied to senior Nigerian government officials and military officers. WAIVER OF PROHIBITIONS AGAINST NIGERIA IF CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS MET. The President can waive prohibitions for Nigeria if certain conditions are met, including respecting human rights and democracy, implementing a transition program, releasing political prisoners, and allowing international human rights monitors access. The President can waive prohibitions for Nigeria if conditions are met, including releasing political prisoners, providing access for human rights monitors, repealing laws granting undue military powers, and ensuring policing in oil communities is done without excessive force or human rights violations. The President can waive prohibitions for Nigeria if conditions are met, including releasing political prisoners, providing access for human rights monitors, repealing laws granting undue military powers, and ensuring policing in oil-producing communities is done without excessive force or human rights violations. Congressional notification is required 15 days in advance of any waiver. SEC. 8. REPORT OF CORRUPTION IN NIGERIA.

Within 3 months of this Act's enactment and annually for the next 5 years, the Secretary of State must submit a report on corruption in Nigeria to congressional committees. The report will cover evidence of corruption by government officials, its impact on government services, US business interests, advance fee fraud, and Nigeria's foreign policy. SEC. 9. APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEFINED. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. SEC. 10. TERMINATION DATE. The provisions of this Act will end on September 30, 2004.
